quote: Captain's log, stardate 41242.4.   Our last assignment has taken us   into the remote Omicron Theta   star system, home of our android   crewmember Lieutenant Commander   Data. Although we are due...
... at our next assignment, I have   decided to increase velocity to   warp eight to visit Data's home   planet for a few hours in the   hopes of unraveling some of the   mystery of his beginnings.
Sir, we are now twenty minutes   from Omicron Theta...       ... mark!
Stand by for subwarp; head for   standard orbit of Data's planet.       Wonder why Data hasn't come up   here.
He said he wanted to be alone.   Perhaps it's a bigger moment for   him than we thought.       If he needs a formal invitation,   Ensign, you do the honors.
Yes sir!
Walk!
Data... !
What are you doing?
Sneezing.
Have you got a... a "cold?"
A cold what?
It's a disease my mother says   people used to get.
Ah. But humans still sneeze for   other reasons and I cannot seem   to do it right.
How can you be practicing sneezing   when you're arriving for the first   time at your home planet? Aren't   you interested in that?
More than interested. Fascinated.   One might say agog. But I find   sneezing interesting also.
Confirming Class M reading there.   But...       ... but the sensors aren't showing   any life readings. Not even   vegetation.
Strange. The cruiser that found   Data reported farmland here.
Want to take her into orbit, Data?
No thank you, sir.
Continue on into close parking   orbit.
Aye, sir.
I could say "home, sweet home,"   sir... if I understood how the   word sweet applies.
It usually refers to the memories.
But usually one's own memories,   Captain.       Do the memories you were given   include "farms?"
Affirmative, sir. Turning soil,   seeding, harvesting... but the   colony's principal interest was   science.
Data, I can't understand how you   can hold the memories of four   hundred eleven people. If that   means every experience, every day   they lived...
It does not, unfortunately. It   means only the knowledge they had   accumulated. Actually, I am quite   deficient in some basic human   information.       Sneezing, for example.
"Sneezing?"
Approaching close parking orbit,   sir.
Assemble your away party,   Commander.
This is an exciting moment for   you, Data. I'm tempted to lead   the away team down myself, except   for the fact the first officer   would object...
How would Starfleet judge me if   I didn't, sir? An entire Earth   colony did disappear down there.
You have no memory at all of what   happened to them, Data?
My final memory is of great   danger, something sudden and not   understood... then a blank as if   the colonists were gone.
Now in close parking orbit, sir.
Welcome home, Mister Data.
Recording signal now locked onto   the Enterprise, sir.
This looks like anything but   farmland.
Agreed, sir. The soil here's   completely lifeless.
This is the exact position listed   in the Tripoli log.    (turning   Do you recognize anything, Data?
The land contours are familiar,   sir. Topographically, this is   the correct area.
This once was rich farmland. I'd   guess something like twenty to   thirty years ago...
I was discovered twenty-six years   ago...

There is still plant cellulose   in the soil. No signs of decay.   Also no signs of bacteria either.       If you don't mind a wild guess,   sir, I'd say everything on this   planet could have been dead or   dying at the time Data was found.
The Tripoli log stated that all   plant life appeared brown and   "dormant." They assumed it was   normal for that season.
... whereas actually everything   was dying...
(interrupting;     indicating)   I was found twenty meters in that   direction, sir.
Data, any idea at all why you were   given the colonists' memories?
I have always felt that it was   done hurriedly, but I know little   more.
Here, sir. This is where the   cruiser's landing party found   the signal device that had led   them here.       And they found me lying there,   sir.
You were just lying out in the   open? No identity record, no   instructions... ?
Only a layer of dust.
There's much more of it now, after   twenty-six years.
What is the first thing you   remember, Data?
Opening my eyes and finding myself   looking into the eyes of the   Tripoli landing party, sir.
(indicating the path     back)   They believed that the signal   device sensed their presence,   and activated me.
Then this very spot was your   birthplace...
But not at all like a human birth.   Having the colonists' memories,   I knew immediately how to speak,   who I was, where I was...
You were born and became fully   knowledgeable at the same instant!
I had no idea that was unusual,   of course.
It's such a strange place to be   born.
So was a manger.
A "manger," sir?
I won't even try to explain that   one, Worf...
I understand now, sir! I've got   this figured!
It was really very cleverly done   to make this look like a natural   hollow in the terrain here.   Signs of it being constructed   hurriedly...
... as if to hide something here.

Yes, that was it, Geordi.       This has awakened a memory   remnant of how the colonists   hoped to remain hidden...       ... but their fear of being   discovered led to their storing   information in me.
Yes, I thought so.
No life readings in here either,   sir.
scene: 10   INT. UNDERGROUND COMPLEX - ANGLE INTO THE ENTRY

quote: The colony laboratory, I'd guess.   Extremely well equipped.       Does this place stir any memories,   Data?
Only vague impressions of some   of my functions being tested   here, sir...
Posted by a proud parent...
This pictures something that feels   familiar, sir. And dangerous,   although I have no idea what it   represents. And that is all...
... except for an impression that   this was a... "Doctor Soong's"   work area.
Who? You can't mean Doctor   Noonien Soong?
He was called that here...   although, his memories indicate   he traveled here under a different   name.
Doctor Noonien Soong, my friend,   just happens to have been Earth's   foremost robotics scientist!
Until he tried to make Asimov's   dream of a positronic brain come   true.

The positronic brain. He promised   it would do so much. When it   failed completely, Doctor Soong   disappeared.       Now we know he went off somewhere   to try a second time.       Geordi, Data, we'll take a close   look at this lab.       You and Lieutenant Worf   reconnoiter where the rest of   these corridors lead.
Data... it's you.
An epidermal mold, I'd guess.   Made to give your exterior the   desired finish.
Lieutenant Yar to Commander Riker.
Come in, Lieutenant.
Sir... this installation is big   enough to hold hundreds of people.   But all that's here now is empty   beds.
Thank you, Lieutenant. Complete   your record scans, then report   back here.
Sir...       Seems to be a storage area here...
How many more Datas are there?
Looks like just these two...       I mean that and the real Data.
Commander, can this be another   me? Or perhaps my brother?
I honestly don't know, Data.
He needs assembling.
"He?" Data, we don't know that   this could become "alive."
It is of great interest to me to   find out, sir. I never believed it   possible I might have a link with   some form like my own.
Understood. We'll take it back   to the ship, of course.
Captain, I have a subspace reply   to your request.       Starfleet considers it vital we   begin our ship's computer upgrade   at Starbase Armus Nine on   schedule.
Damn. Can anyone see why they've   turned down a perfectly legitimate   request to finish this   investigation here?
Sir... you asked for the kind of   computer upgrade that only the   Bynars can handle. And they're   available only at this time.
Then, get us there on schedule,   Number One.    (to Wesley; controlling     self)   Thank you, Wesley. I'd completely   forgotten that.
Take us out of orbit, Mister La   Forge.
Captain's log, Stardate 41242.45.   Despite having only a few hours   in which to explore Data's home   planet...
... we have discovered something   which may explain Data's   beginnings... if we can properly   assemble and communicate with what   we've found.
Signal from the captain. They   need you at the debriefing.
I've been anxious to hear the   chief engineer's opinion, Mister   Argyle. Do you believe he can   be made to function?
It appears to include all the   components in your body. Not that   we really understand your   construction either...
We'll have our top medical and   engineering specialists working   on its assembly, Mister Data.
Just... one thing. Without   disassembling you, of course, if   we should need...
... If we should need to compare   this with the way... uh, with the   way you're put together... ?
Bringing it up here was the right   thing to do, of course, Number   One.
I was just saying, Data, that if   it functions, it might answer a   lot of questions for us.
Does it appear to have all   your... ah, parts?
Completely, sir.
Will we know how to... to "turn   it on?"

All right, all right...    (stands; hesitates,     then)   Legitimate questions about this   need not be asked apologetically.       You're uncomfortable about aspects   of your duplicate, Data... we're   uncomfortable, too... and none of   it for any logical reason. We   know that you're as "alive" as   any of the rest of us.       If you find it awkward to be   reminded that Data is a   "machine"... you might remember   that the rest of you are merely   a different variety of   machine... in our case,   electro-chemical in nature.
Let's begin handling this as we   would anything else.
Agreed! Love that captain!
My comments, Lieutenant, do not   require applause!
Yes, sir; sorry, sir.
Let's start with you, Data.
Well... a good starting point might   be, "Why was I given human form?"
To make it easy for humans to   relate to you. Had to be. But   your designer may have had   something else to prove also.
That human-shaped robots need not   be clumsy, limited things...       You certainly operate as well as   we do, Data...
In some ways better, sir.
Ah... yes! But the important   question now may be what happened   to the colonists.

Agreed.    (exhibits child's     drawing)   One of several exhibited in the   lab, by proud parents, no doubt.   This could be simply a child's   imagination. But then, several   children made similar drawings.
Doctor Crusher to Captain. At   this point, sir, we very much need   Mister Data's help.
He's on his way, Doctor.
There, Doctor. Press your fingers   there.
It operates somewhat like a   "switch," Doctor.
And these small projections?
An android alarm clock, Doctor.   Is that amusing?       It times how long I remain   unconscious.
Are you certain about us using   these heating devices, Data?
I will feel nothing at all.
Marvelous. It should all be a   lot simpler... once we can see how   your circuitry's connected.
I'll mention it to no one. You   have my word.
If you had an off-switch   Doctor... would you not keep it   secret?
I probably would.
Yes, notice the micro-circuitry   here... and here.
Then another fibroid-like   connection here.
Let's close up.
If I've done it right, he'll   switch on in a minute.
It seemed to go well...       ... thanks to a look inside Mister   Data. But there have been no   signs of consciousness, yet...
Certainly a perfect match for   Data, sir.
Do you think so, really?       I wonder which of them was made   first?
He was. But they found him   imperfect and I was made to   replace him.
You may call me Lore.
I'm also a bit troubled by it   describing you as "imperfect."
Human language gives me   difficulties too, sir.   "Imperfect" could mean I lack   abilities that he possesses.
I wonder. But the point of this   is whether you and it have   approximately the same   capabilities.
We do, sir, and your referring   to him as an "it"... suggests I   too fit into the category of a   "thing."
I see your point, Commander. My   sincere apologies.
Gladly accepted, sir. As for   Lore's abilities, his use of   syntax and grammar suggests he   was given human memories similar   to mine.
You both have about equal   physical strength and mental   ability?
I believe so, sir.
Which requires I now ask you... a   very serious question. Since the   two of you are closely related   to each other...
The answer, sir, is that my   loyalty is to you and Starfleet.   Completely.
Thank you, Commander. I was   certain of that.
And Helm control are here, with   the ship's heading given in   measurements, we call them   "degrees"...       ... with three hundred-sixty of   them in a full circle this way.
... Then you say "mark"...
On the nose!
Which separates it from another   three hundred-sixty degree full   circle like this... on a right   angle to that one.
So by ordering a heading so many   degrees this way, and so many this   way, the ship can travel in any   direction. All three dimensions.
And the square of the hypotenuse   of a right triangle...
Is equal to the sum of the square   of its other two...       ... its two "somethings"... which   I once heard but never understood.
All of which you can learn more   about, when the captain has   approved your being on the bridge.
(surprise and     contrition)   Have I committed an offense?
You'll find as I have that   starships are loaded with rules   which have to be learned.
You're very clever, Wesley.       I now have duties to perform.   Correct?
Were you ever this anxious to   please, Data?
Never. I judge Lore to be   superior in that desire as well.
Because I was designed to be so   human, my brother, I enjoy pleasing   humans.
"My brother." That has a nice   sound, Data.
And you consider it important to   please humans?
It's not important?
There are many things of   importance... some more so than   others.
My quarters.
Is my brother that important?   It knows you?
It can identify any of the crew.       Just as I can identify flattery,   brother.
I used it only to please you, my   brother. Is that forbidden too?
It is best used when it reflects   genuine feelings.
Then, I used it properly with you.
Do you realize Commander Riker's   hypotenuse question tricked you   into showing your knowledge was   much greater than you were   indicating?
He didn't seem that clever. I'll   be more careful.
You tend to underestimate humans,   my brother. The way you praised   young Wesley at the Helm, for   example...
A child!
He has a child's body, but we have   found him to be much more than that.
Thank you for that information,   too.       You do care about how I perform.   I pledge to be worthy of your   teaching, my brother.
How would they describe this?   "Spartan?"
I have no need for places to sit   or sleep. Do you?
Do I appear that weak?
What information are you   requesting?
Everything available on a Doctor   Noonien Soong.
Good old "Often-Wrong Soong."       A joke, brother. Actually, he   was a genius by human standards.
(reading computer     viewer)   But had destroyed his own   reputation by making what seemed   wild promises about his positronic   brain design... almost all of which   failed.
Promises he later proved to be   true...       Which made you and I possible.   Our beloved "father."       Will I soon have a uniform like   that, my brother?
If you get one the way I did,   Lore, it means four years at the   Academy, another three as ensign,   ten or twelve on varied space duty   in the lieutenant grades...

... A system designed to compensate   for limited human abilities.   But you, my brother, have begun   thinking as humans do. You and   I are completely different from   them. Are you truly satisfied   with the memories and knowledge   of just a few hundred human   colonists? Suppose it could   reflect thousands... or a   million... or the knowledge of   hundreds of millions of life forms   of every kind?
How?
We will discuss it in time.
And will we also discuss which   of us was constructed first?

It would be foolish to   underestimate you, my brother.       Yes, I lied when I said you were   made first. With good reason.   Doctor Soong made me perfect on   his first attempt. But he made   me so completely human that the   colonists became envious of me.
You lived with the colonists?
Until they petitioned Soong to   design a more comfortable, less   perfect android. In other words,   you, my brother.
For example, haven't you noticed   how easily I handle human speech?   I use their contractions... such   as isn't or can't. You say...       ... is not or cannot.
I say tomato, you say tomahto;   I say potato, you say potahto...       A very old joke, but you also   have trouble with their humor,   too. Am I right?
Quite true. I keep trying to be   more human... and keep failing.
Do you realize, my brother, that   I can help you become more human?
And... do you realize... Lore,   that I am obligated to report all   of this to our ship's captain?
I assumed as much when I began   studying you.       May I use this to learn more of   this vessel and its customs?
Use it also to describe for the   captain the time you spent with   the colonists. Including all   you know about what happened to   them.
I promise a report with great   detail and accuracy.
Thank you, Lore. And now, I   have duties to perform, unless   you need something more.
I have more than I dreamed   possible, my brother.
Captain's log, stardate 41242.5.   We now have the full story of the   micro-engineering achievement   which produced Data... and Lore...
... and of the tragedy which   deprived humanity of the   remarkable minds behind that.   Our first clue was a child's   drawing which showed a great,   complex crystal shape...

... confirmed by Lore's report to   be an unknown kind of creature,   capable of stripping all life from   an entire world... insatiably   ravenous for the life force found   in intelligent forms like   us... which Lore explains it stored   in new crystal patterns... for   purposes which are unknown.
But how did Data escape that   thing? Or Lore?
Lore had been disassembled. He   explains it as jealousy from the   colonists. And Data wasn't yet   "alive" at that time.

Which explains why Data could be   left outside in no danger from   the creature. Whatever happened   to the colonists, he would be   found by any Starfleet team that   responded to the signal being   transmitted.
By which Doctor Soong left proof   behind that his experiment did   work.
Captain, how believable do you   find that crystal thing?
Having explored so little of just   our galaxy, I find anything   possible.
(overlapping; puzzled     by readings)   Data, are you expecting Lore to   come up here? He left your   quarters some time ago.
To go... ?
My Turbo-sensors say he went to   Deck One...       Worf?
... where he examined some   microminiature work tools, then   some...       ... fine grind quadratanium... ?
Which is used in our construction.       That particular compound is no   more suspicious, sir, than a human   looking for an antiseptic or an   ointment. Nevertheless, I should   check it out.
You're watching everything he   does, Data? Is that the act of   a brother?
The act of a Starfleet officer   obeying his captain, Doctor.
Speaking strictly as security   chief, Captain... how much can you   trust Data now?
I trust him completely,   Lieutenant!       But everyone should also realize   you just asked a necessary and   legitimate security question.
Thank you for explaining that,   sir.
Lesson one in becoming more human,   my brother. You must observe all   human customs.
Champagne?

An ancient ritual, still practiced   when they celebrate events of   importance.    (picking up undoctored     glass)   My brother... I toast our   discovery of each other. May it   fill our lives with new meaning.
I have some doubts about the value   of human... customs in this...my...   brother...
And let us toast also...
Brother... help me...
... also Doctor Soong who gave me   the full richness of human needs   and ambitions... a perfect match   for my mind, my body...
And let us toast also the great   Crystal Entity... with which I   learned to communicate. Before   Doctor Soong disassembled me, I   earned its gratitude by revealing   the way to the colonists.
Can you image its gratitude when   I give it the life on this   vessel... and when my cleverness   lets it safely feed upon crowded   worlds in the galaxy... ?
This is strange, sir. I show   Mister Data transmitting on a   subspace channel.
He's been doing considerable   research on Doctor Soong's   background... but let's be sure.       Wesley, can you look in on him   discreetly?
(coming to his feet     instantly)   Yes sir!
... and upon arriving here you can   identify me as the machine named   "Data."
End of message.       Come in, please.
Glad you are here, Wesley. Lore   suddenly attacked me and I had   to turn him off.
Why did he do that, Data?
He discovered we have been   using sensors to follow what   he does.
I practiced his facial "tic."   Do I have it right?
I'd suggest you forget imitating   him...       ... because if you had said "We've   been using the sensors," instead   if "we have," I might have   suspected you were Lore.
Yes. I do use language more   formally than Lore. Please   inform the captain I will come   up to the bridge...    (indicating unconscious     Form)   ... and report on this.
Aye, sir.
You're certain he said he'll be   right up?
He indicated that, sir.
Sensors show Data just now   entering a turbolift, sir.
Wes, tell me again how Data said   he immobilized Lore.
He said he "turned him off," Mom...       ... uh, Doctor.
Question, Mister Data... did you   or did you not swear me to secrecy   about your "off switch?"
A change of mind, Doctor. If I   cannot trust the bridge crew, whom   can I... ?
(interrupting; to     Picard)   Sir! I'm picking up a "bogey"   coming in on a five o'clock   tangent.
Confirm! And so fast it makes   our warp eight look like we're   standing still!
It's transmitting no ID signal,   Captain...
Set Main Viewer on that tangent.
Shields up; go to Yellow Alert!   Transmit friendly greetings, all   languages, all frequencies.
I can't believe anything   overtaking us this fast.
Beautiful, isn't it?
I recognize it, Captain... it's   similar to that child's drawing...
My God, it's big!
Still no ID transmitted, sir.   Also, no answer to our inquiries.
Did you have a direct look at it?
It's like a snowflake crystal,   sir. But much more complex... the   entire electromagnetic spectrum   seems to play about inside it...       I haven't the slightest idea what   it is, sir.
Data, anything else Lore can tell   us about it may be important.   Can you control Lore enough to   question him?
(rising; moving to     turbolift)   I'll have to examine him to know,   sir.
Captain, recommend you do not   let...       ... him move around the ship alone.
Ensign... !
(interrupting;     chuckling)   Wesley is only trying to show   himself alert and responsible,   sir.       Something to encourage. Come,   you can watch everything I do.
Not if I have a choice.
That is quite enough, Ensign!   When addressing a senior   officer...
I've guided his training; I'm the   one at fault, sir.       You will show proper courtesy,   and I'm taking you down there to   make certain of it!       With your approval, of course,   sir.
Careful of Lore...       Good, he is still unconscious.
The captain refused to listen to   you but you were right... Lore   can be extremely dangerous.
Notice? The same twitch, even   when he's unconscious... I suspect   that...
... something went seriously wrong   during Lore's construction.
Stay back. We could have a   problem if he senses someone else   is near.    (bringing android     closer)   Lore, I have some questions to   ask you...
Lore, it is Data. I have a few   easy questions for you...    (pretending to control     Data)   He senses you!       I'm sorry, I can't control him   if you stay.
Please! I'll record anything he   says!
And bring it to the bridge.   Immediately!
And you want to be as stupid as   them... ?
... dear brother!
Well, Number One?
Sir, it's Lore... with the same   facial twitch we've all seen...   lying unconscious exactly as Data   described. But he became violent,   apparently sensing that Wesley   and I were present...
Or is it Lore pretending to be   Data, and faking it all?
I asked for Commander Riker's   report, "Acting Ensign" Crusher.   And since it is now clear you are   unable to function here within   the limits of that appointment...
Captain!
Deflector shields holding, sir.
Bring photon torpedoes to ready;   main phasers to ready...
Go to Red Alert, please.
Weapons now ready, sir!
No, Captain, let me talk to it...
Why didn't you say you could?
Affirmative! Talk to it!

Open hailing frequencies!       Crystal Form, I identify myself   as "Data," advising you to stop   your attack. The humans here are   powerful, capable of injuring or   even destroying you. They can   be changed only in other ways.
Now I call that communicating.
But he mentioned "changing us,"   Captain. What does that mean?

It has many meanings, as any human   language dictionary could inform   you.       Suggest moving fast to confirm   what I told it, sir. Permission   to use the large transporter in   Cargo Room Three? There I can   beam out some living pattern,   perhaps a large tree...
Which you'll beam over next to   the entity...
You are correct, Riker.       Our ship's phasers will then blast   and disintegrate it... proving   we're dangerous.
Make it so!
Sir?
Do it!
Sir, I know this may finish me   as an acting ensign, but...
Shut up, Wesley.       Lieutenant Yar, pick a good   security team, let me know what   he does.
"Shut up, Wesley?"
Stay out of this, Madam...
Since I am finished here, Captain,   may I point out... ?
Shut up, Wesley!
... that what I've said would have   been listened to if it came from   an adult officer. Request   permission to return to my   quarters, sir.
Granted, if you take your mother   with you.
You're putting me off the bridge?
I'm asking that you keep an eye   on your son during this, Doctor.
Please, Mom. Let's go.
Emergency close!
Now show me your warrior   fierceness.
I'll look, but I should never   have let you talk me into this...
It's Data, Mom. He's been hurt!
It's Data! For once will you   trust me about something?
You must know how much Starfleet   means to me. But I'm finished   unless you can help me.       I heard you know how to turn them   on. Please?
No, this is very serious...
I know, Mom. So tell me again   to "shut up, Wesley," and I will.
You're being very unfair,   Wesley...
Data, the Crystal Thing is outside   close to the ship... and Lore is   loose somewhere inside.
How badly are you hurt... Data?
I will function sufficiently to   stop Lore, Doctor...
Whatever happens, it is important   that you two stay away from him.   Do not try to help me.
Good, you understand perfectly   so far. Next, I'll signal I'm   about to transport something   out...
... at which time the deflector   shields will turn off for a   moment, and if you move in at   that time...
How sad, dear brother. You have   made me wish I were an only child.
Then why this marvelous gift, my   brother? The troublesome little   man-child.       Are you prepared for the kind of   death you've earned, little man?
If you take one step toward my   son...
Ah, motherhood!       Back off or I'll turn your little   man into a torch!
I promise him exquisite pain   unless you obey me too, dear   brother.
Move away, Data, please!
Do you see now the advantages of   being completely human?       It includes kindness. I give you   your life, Doctor. Go, quickly   and I may not injure your son at   all.
I will stay with Wesley, Doctor.
Go! Or he'll be shrieking on the   count of five. One... two...
I'll bring help, Wesley.
Thank you for my human quality,   Doctor Soong.       Now a small payment for your son's   misdeeds.
Mom!
Stay back, Wesley! Help me some   other way!
Wesley... now!
Lore's gone, sir, permanently!
Now that your son's safe, Doctor,   report immediately to Sickbay.
Captain... The crystal thing has   begun to move away.
(continuing; beat;     eyeing him)   Data, get rid of that damned   twitch! And put on a correct   uniform.
Yes, Captain.
And Ensign Crusher...       ... are you able to return to duty   now?
Yes, sir!
Then do so! Let the bridge know   all is well down here.
It's gone, sir. Without Lore, it   had no way to reach us.
And we're overdue for our computer   refit.       Number One, have you ever   considered whether Data is more   human, or less human than we want?
I only wish we were as well   balanced, sir.
Agreed!
